content:
EventTrigger Class

In this Article

Represents a trigger that applies a set of actions in response to an event.

Syntax

Declaration

[System.Windows.Markup.ContentProperty("Actions")]
public class EventTrigger : System.Windows.TriggerBase, System.Windows.Markup.IAddChild

Inheritance Hierarchy

  • Object
  • DispatcherObject
  • DependencyObject
  • System.Windows.TriggerBase
  • EventTrigger

Inherited Members

Equals(Object,Object)
,
GetType()
,

,

Remarks

Trigger objects have the Setters, EnterActions, and ExitActions properties that apply changes or actions based on the state of certain properties, while EventTrigger objects start a set of Actions when a specified routed event occurs. For example, you may want to use an EventTrigger to start a set of animations when the mouse pointer is over a certain user interface (UI) control. Unlike Trigger, EventTrigger has no concept of termination of state, so the action will not be undone once the condition that raised the event is no longer true.

Note that when using an EventTrigger, you need to choose events that do not interfere with the inherent behavior of your control. Controls such as Button or TextBox perform specific actions on user input events such as mouse clicks and keyboard events. For example, if you are styling a button and try to set the <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.MouseDown> event as the RoutedEvent of an EventTrigger, the EventTrigger never gets applied because the event first gets handled by the button. Instead, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.PreviewMouseDown> event or a different event.

When using data binding, if you are using the <xref:System.Windows.Data.Binding.TargetUpdated> event, you must set the NotifyOnTargetUpdated value of your Binding object to true for the event to be raised.

Adding a TriggerAction child to an EventTrigger object implicitly adds it to the TriggerActionCollection for the EventTrigger object.

Constructors summary

EventTrigger()

Initializes a new instance of the EventTrigger class.
EventTrigger(RoutedEvent)

Initializes a new instance of the EventTrigger class with the specified event.

Properties summary

Actions

Gets the collection of actions to apply when the event occurs.
RoutedEvent

Gets or sets the RoutedEvent that will activate this trigger.
SourceName

Gets or sets the name of the object with the event that activates this trigger. This is only used by element triggers or template triggers.

Methods summary

AddChild(Object)

Adds the specified object to the stem.Windows.EventTrigger.Actions* collection of the current event trigger.
AddText(String)

This method is not supported and results in an exception.
ShouldSerializeActions()

Returns whether serialization processes should serialize the effective value of the stem.Windows.EventTrigger.Actions* property on instances of this class.

Explicit Interface Implementations summary

IAddChild.AddChild(Object)

Adds a child object.
IAddChild.AddText(String)

Adds the text content of a node to the object.

Constructors

  • EventTrigger()

    Initializes a new instance of the EventTrigger class.

    public EventTrigger ();
  • EventTrigger(RoutedEvent)

    Initializes a new instance of the EventTrigger class with the specified event.

    public EventTrigger (System.Windows.RoutedEvent routedEvent);

    Parameters

    • routedEvent
      RoutedEvent

      The RoutedEvent that activates this trigger.

Properties

  • Actions

    Gets the collection of actions to apply when the event occurs.

    public System.Windows.TriggerActionCollection Actions { get; }

    Property Value

    • TriggerActionCollection

      The default is an empty collection.

    Remarks

    Unlike Trigger, EventTrigger has no concept of termination of state, so the action will not be undone once the condition that raised the event is no longer true.

    Adding a TriggerAction child to an EventTrigger object implicitly adds it to the TriggerActionCollection for the EventTrigger object.

    Note

    This property can only be set in Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML) via the collection syntax shown, or by accessing the collection object and using its various methods such as Add. The property to access the collection object itself is read-only, the collection itself is read-write.

    XAML Property Element Usage

    <object>  
  <object.Actions>  
    OneOrMoreTriggerActions  
  </object.Actions>  
</object>

    XAML Values

    OneOrMoreTriggerActions
    One or more TriggerAction objects.

    Example

    This example describes how to use event triggers in a style to animate the MouseEnter and MouseLeave events of a FrameworkElement. As mentioned above, adding a TriggerAction child to an EventTrigger object implicitly adds it to the TriggerActionCollection for the EventTrigger object. Therefore, in this example, <EventTrigger.Actions> is implicit. 

    <Style TargetType="Rectangle">
  <Setter Property="Width" Value="50" />
  <Setter Property="Height" Value="50" />
  <Setter Property="Margin" Value="20" />
  <Setter Property="HorizontalAlignment" Value="Left" />
  <Style.Triggers>
    <EventTrigger RoutedEvent="MouseEnter">
        <BeginStoryboard>
            <Storyboard>
              <DoubleAnimation To="300" Duration="0:0:1.5" 
                AccelerationRatio="0.10" DecelerationRatio="0.25" 
                Storyboard.TargetProperty="(Canvas.Width)" />
            </Storyboard>
        </BeginStoryboard>
    </EventTrigger>
    <EventTrigger RoutedEvent="MouseLeave">
        <BeginStoryboard>
            <Storyboard>
              <DoubleAnimation Duration="0:0:1.5" 
                AccelerationRatio="0.10" DecelerationRatio="0.25" 
                Storyboard.TargetProperty="(Canvas.Width)" />
            </Storyboard>
        </BeginStoryboard>
    </EventTrigger>
  </Style.Triggers>
</Style>

    This snippet ID eventtriggersnippet is used in multiple files: /CS/Default.xaml, /XAML/Default.xaml. Rename the duplicate ID to make it unique, and update the reference to the snippet ID in the topic(s).
  • RoutedEvent

    Gets or sets the RoutedEvent that will activate this trigger.

    public System.Windows.RoutedEvent RoutedEvent { get; set; }

    Property Value

    • RoutedEvent

      The default value is null.

    Exceptions

    • ArgumentNullException

      The RoutedEvent property cannot be null.

    Remarks

    EventTriggers apply a set of actions when the specified routed event occurs. For example, you may want to use EventTriggers to start a set of animations when the mouse pointer is over a certain user interface (UI) control.

    If the template or style that contains this EventTrigger does not have the TargetType property specified, then you need to quality the event name with the class name using the ClassName.EventName syntax.

    EventTrigger objects cannot handle events that have already been Handled. Controls such as Button or TextBox perform specific actions on user input events such as mouse clicks and keyboard events. For example, if you are styling a button and try to set the <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.MouseDown> event as the RoutedEvent of an EventTrigger, the EventTrigger never gets applied because the event first gets handled by the button. Instead, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.PreviewMouseDown> event or a different event.

    When using data binding, if you are using the <xref:System.Windows.Data.Binding.TargetUpdated> event, you must set the NotifyOnTargetUpdated value of your Binding object to true for the event to be raised.

    Example

    This example shows how to use event triggers in a style to animate the MouseEnter and MouseLeave events of a FrameworkElement. In this example, the Style has the TargetType set to Rectangle. Therefore, there is no need to qualify the MouseEnter and MouseLeave event names with the class name. 

    <Style TargetType="Rectangle">
  <Setter Property="Width" Value="50" />
  <Setter Property="Height" Value="50" />
  <Setter Property="Margin" Value="20" />
  <Setter Property="HorizontalAlignment" Value="Left" />
  <Style.Triggers>
    <EventTrigger RoutedEvent="MouseEnter">
        <BeginStoryboard>
            <Storyboard>
              <DoubleAnimation To="300" Duration="0:0:1.5" 
                AccelerationRatio="0.10" DecelerationRatio="0.25" 
                Storyboard.TargetProperty="(Canvas.Width)" />
            </Storyboard>
        </BeginStoryboard>
    </EventTrigger>
    <EventTrigger RoutedEvent="MouseLeave">
        <BeginStoryboard>
            <Storyboard>
              <DoubleAnimation Duration="0:0:1.5" 
                AccelerationRatio="0.10" DecelerationRatio="0.25" 
                Storyboard.TargetProperty="(Canvas.Width)" />
            </Storyboard>
        </BeginStoryboard>
    </EventTrigger>
  </Style.Triggers>
</Style>

    This snippet ID eventtriggersnippet is used in multiple files: /CS/Default.xaml, /XAML/Default.xaml. Rename the duplicate ID to make it unique, and update the reference to the snippet ID in the topic(s).
  • SourceName

    Gets or sets the name of the object with the event that activates this trigger. This is only used by element triggers or template triggers.

    public string SourceName { get; set; }

    Property Value

    • String

      The default value is null. If this property value is null, then the element being monitored for the raising of the event is the templated parent or the logical tree root.

    Exceptions

    • InvalidOperationException

      After an EventTrigger is in use, it cannot be modified.

    Remarks

    You can set this property to the name of any element within the scope of where the trigger collection (the collection that this EventTrigger is part of) is applied. This is typically a named element that is within the template that contains this EventTrigger. If you are setting the Triggers property on an element directly, then it is a named element within the scope of that parent element.

    You can name an object using the x:Name Directive syntax.

Methods

  • AddChild(Object)

    Adds the specified object to the stem.Windows.EventTrigger.Actions* collection of the current event trigger.

    protected virtual void AddChild (object value);

    Parameters

    • value
      Object

      A TriggerAction object to add to the stem.Windows.EventTrigger.Actions* collection of this trigger.

  • AddText(String)

    This method is not supported and results in an exception.

    protected virtual void AddText (string text);

    Parameters

    • text
      String

      This parameter is not used.

  • ShouldSerializeActions()

    Returns whether serialization processes should serialize the effective value of the stem.Windows.EventTrigger.Actions* property on instances of this class.

    public bool ShouldSerializeActions ();

    Returns

    • Boolean

      Returns trueif the stem.Windows.EventTrigger.Actions* property value should be serialized; otherwise, false.

Explicit Interface Implementations

  • IAddChild.AddChild(Object)

    Adds a child object.

    void IAddChild.AddChild (object value);

    Parameters

    • value
      Object

      The child object to add.

    Remarks

    This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the EventTrigger instance is cast to an IAddChild interface.

  • IAddChild.AddText(String)

    Adds the text content of a node to the object.

    void IAddChild.AddText (string text);

    Parameters

    • text
      String

      The text to add to the object.

    Remarks

    This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the EventTrigger instance is cast to an IAddChild interface.
